isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 9200, 9300, 9400 Models Built After January 1, 1995 - BATTERY, CHARGING & CRANKING SYSTEMS - TROUBLESHOOTING - STARTING MOTOR SYSTEM CIRCUITS AND COMPONENTS

svcproc.title: STARTING MOTOR SYSTEM CIRCUITS AND COMPONENTS

svcprocinfo.para: Troubleshooting tests for the starting motor system circuits and components.

svcsubproc.title: Starter Solenoid Circuit Test - Part 1
svcsubproc.para: Starter shifting in and out, or not pulling in, is often caused by high resistance in the starter solenoid circuit. When the solenoid circuit has excessive voltage loss, the starter pinion sometimes may not engage the flywheel. If it does engage, it may drop out too soon when battery voltage drops. The solenoid circuit includes the starter magnetic switch and leads connected to the starter solenoid.
On vehicles with overcrank protection, refer to Testing Thermal Overcrank Protection System before performing this test.

step1.para: Disconnect circuit 17C from the starter solenoid. Connect the carbon pile to the magnetic switch and to the starter ground. Connect the voltmeter to battery cable ends at starter (not to carbon pile clamp).

Have an assistant push the starter button. You should hear the start magnetic switch energize with a clicking sound. (If the switch doesn't "click," either the magnetic switch is defective or there is no voltage from the key switch circuit.)

Adjust the carbon pile to 80 amps load. Measure and record
the voltage at the battery cable connections to the starter. Release the start button.
Move the voltmeter lead from the BATT terminal of the starter solenoid to the end of circuit 17C that is connected to the carbon pile.
Push and hold the start button again and readjust the carbon pile load to 80 amps.Measure and record voltage to the solenoid. Release the start button.

svcsubproc.para: Cable Voltage (step 3)
minus Solenoid Voltage (step 5)
equalsCircuit Loss =
If circuit loss is 1.0 volt or less, go to Starter Magnetic Switch Circuit Test - Part 1
If circuit loss is more than 1.0 volt, go to Starter Solenoid Circuit Test - Part 2

svcsubproc.title: Starter Solenoid Circuit Test - Part 2
svcsubproc.para: If the voltage loss in Test 1 was more than 1 volt, the loss is excessive. The loss may be from loose terminals, corrosion, or a worn out start magnetic switch. To locate the problem:

step1.para: Disconnect circuit 17C from S terminal at start solenoid. Connect carbon pile to circuit 17C and to starter ground terminal. Turn the carbon pile ON (will show 0 amps).
Connect DMM from solenoid BAT terminal to large terminal of magnetic switch. If voltage shows on meter, move meter lead to the other large magnetic switch terminal.
Push start button with key ON. Adjust carbon pile to 80 amp load. Measure and record first wire voltage loss. Release button.
Connect DMM to other (opposite) large terminal on magnetic switch and to circuit 17C (connect to terminal and not to carbon pile clamp).
Push start button - adjust carbon pile to 80 amp load. Measure and record second wire voltage loss. Release start button.

svcsubproc.para: First Wire Loss (step 3)
plus Second Wire Loss (step 5)
equals Total Wiring Loss = (0.8v maximum loss)
If circuit loss is 0.8 volt or less, go to step 6.
If circuit loss is more than 0.8 volt, repair or replace wire, then go to step 6.

step1.para: Connect DMM across the two large magnetic switch terminals (voltage will show immediately).
Push start button and adjust carbon pile to 80 amp load. Measure and record voltage loss across the magnetic switch.
If the voltage drop is greater than 0.5 volts, replace the magnetic switch.
Leave circuit 17C disconnected (use tape to insulate) to perform Starter Magnetic Switch Circuit Test - Part 1.

svcsubproc.title: Starter Magnetic Switch Circuit Test - Part 1
svcsubproc.para: A magnetic switch that does not close or drops out too soon can be caused by high resistance or an open in the control circuit.

step1.para: Disconnect (insulate with tape) circuit 17C from start solenoid S terminal. Connect voltmeter to the starter BAT and GND terminals.

With key switch ON, push starter button.You should hear the magnetic switch relay click." If not, proceed. Measure and record
battery cable voltage. Release start switch.
Connect the voltmeter to the small magnetic switch terminal and to ground.(Magnetic switch is internally grounded through the mounting.)
Push the start button (with key ON). Measure and record magnetic switch voltage. Release the start switch.

svcsubproc.para: Battery Cable Voltage (step 2)
minus Magnetic Switch Voltage (step 4)
equals Control Circuit Wiring Loss =
If circuit loss is 0.5 volt or less and the magnetic switch closes, end the test.
If circuit loss is 0.5 volt or less and the magnetic switch doesn't close, replace the switch and repeat the test.
If circuit loss is more than 0.5 volt, go to Starter Magnetic Switch Circuit Test - Part 2.

svcsubproc.title: Starter Magnetic Switch Circuit Test - Part 2
svcsubproc.para: If Test Starter Magnetic Switch Circuit Test - Part 1 has shown a voltage loss greater than 0.5V, perform this test using a digital multimeter (DMM).

step1.para: With the key ON and start button depressed:

step2.para: Measure and record solenoid to key voltage.
Measure and record key switch voltage.
Measure and record key to start button.
Measure and record start button to magnetic switch.
Measure and record magnetic switch ground to starter ground.

svcsubproc.para: TOTAL (0.5V MAX. ALLOWED)

If any of the circuits or component checks (A through F) show full battery voltage with the start button depressed, then an open circuit exists in the portion of the circuit between the DMM leads. Repair that portion and connect circuit 17C to the starter solenoid.

item.para: Cold Weather Start Magnetic Switch Problems
If all previous battery tests have been performed, the vehicle batteries and starter wiring have been checked.

The starter magnetic switch can fail to "hold in" during cold weather cranking due to low voltage, even though the switches and circuits check OK. With this failure you will hear the starter failing to stay engaged with the flywheel. It is caused by low system voltage releasing the magnetic switch.

If this condition exists, have an assistant clamp a heavy battery jumper cable between the two big (5/16") studs on the magnetic switch while cranking. Caution - The studs are battery voltage and the engine should crank when the jumper is connected. Remove jumper to stop cranking.
If the engine cranks properly with jumper in place, replace the magnetic switch and make sure starter mounting bolts are tight.
If all previous battery tests have been performed, the vehicle batteries and starter wiring have been checked, but the engine still cranks slowly, check available voltage at the starter.

step1.para: While cranking engine, measure voltage between the starter BATT terminal and starter ground.

step2.para: If voltage is 9.0 volts or more, the problem must be in the starter (or engine). Replace the starter.
If the voltage is less than 9.0 volts, go to step 2.

step1.para: Check the interconnecting cable between the batteries. While cranking, measure the terminal voltage of each battery by touching voltmeter leads to the post of each battery.

step2.para: If the difference between any two batteries readings in the same battery box is more than 0.5 volts or any cable is warm to the touch, replace the interconnecting cables.
If cables check OK, the problem must be in the starter (or engine). Replace the starter.

With key in start position, at connector (275) measure voltage to gnd. at circuit 17B.

With key in start position, at connector (275) measure voltage between circuits 17B and 17-G.
